Two men had to be taken to hospital after a vicious homophobic attack on a tram. 
The victims, both in their 40s, were travelling on a Metrolink service from Media City heading into the city centre when they became involved in a row with another man and two women. 
Just before the tram reached Cornbrook, the group then launched a violent attack on the ‘innocent’ pair, punching and kicking them while subjecting them to a tirade of homophobic abuse. 
Both victims had to be taken to hospital for treatment to their injuries. 
Police have launched an investigation into the attack which they are treating as a hate crime. Detectives have released CCTV images of two people they would like to speak to Read More Man filmed yelling vile racist abuse at bus passenger 
And detectives have now released pictures of two people they would like to speak to in connection with the incident which occurred at around 10.30pm on Sunday January 22. 
One of the women was white, with long brown hair in a ponytail and was wearing a dark cap. 
She was also wearing a black hoody with a white square and white lettering on the front of it. 
Detective Constable Claire Phythian, from GMP’s Trafford division, said: “This was a disturbing attack on two innocent men as they made their way home. 
“We are doing everything we can to find those responsible for it and with that, we need the public’s help with any information about the incident. Read More Thousands expected to join anti-Donald Trump protest march in city centre 
“If you recognise the people pictured, or have any information about them, then please contact police. 
“If you were on the tram at the time of the offence and witnessed the attack, please also call us. 
“We take all reports of hate crimes extremely seriously and the message is clear – they will not and never will be tolerated in Greater Manchester.” 
Anyone with any information is asked to call 0161 856 7677 quoting incident number 2269 of 22 January 2017. 
Alternatively, information can be passed to Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111. Like us on Facebook
